title: 109_s3738
content: The Act titled "Nonitemizer Real Property Tax Deduction Act of 2006" provides an additional standard deduction for real property taxes for nonitemizers. The Act "Nonitemizer Real Property Tax Deduction Act of 2006" amends the standard deduction to include a real property tax deduction of up to $500 ($1,000 for joint returns) for State and local real property taxes paid. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2006. The Act "Nonitemizer Real Property Tax Deduction Act of 2006" adds a real property tax deduction of up to $500 ($1,000 for joint returns) for State and local real property taxes paid, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2006. Section 7701 is amended to clarify the Economic Substance Doctrine for transactions. The Economic Substance Doctrine for transactions requires that a taxpayer's economic position changes significantly and there is a substantial nontax purpose for the transaction. Financial accounting benefits cannot be considered unless they stem from a reduction of income. The economic substance doctrine requires significant economic changes and a substantial nontax purpose for transactions. Accounting benefits are only considered if they result from a reduction in income tax. The economic substance doctrine requires substantial economic changes and a nontax purpose for transactions. Fees, expenses, and foreign taxes are considered in determining pre-tax profit. Special rules apply for transactions with tax-indifferent parties, especially in financing transactions. The economic substance doctrine requires substantial economic changes and a nontax purpose for transactions, with special rules for transactions with tax-indifferent parties. Deductions claimed should not exceed the present value of anticipated economic returns, and a public offering may be treated as borrowing from a tax-indifferent party if at least 50 percent is placed with them. Artificial income shifting and basis adjustments may not be respected if they result in excessive income allocation to tax-indifferent parties. The economic substance doctrine prohibits tax benefits for transactions lacking economic substance or a business purpose. Special rules apply to transactions with tax-indifferent parties, defined as entities not subject to tax. Excessive income allocation or basis adjustments to tax-indifferent parties are not recognized. The economic substance doctrine prohibits tax benefits for transactions lacking economic substance or a business purpose. Special rules apply to transactions with tax-indifferent parties, defined as entities not subject to tax. Transactions entered into by individuals for personal purposes are exempt from these rules. The subsection provides guidelines on the expected net tax benefits for leased property, excluding depreciation, tax credits, or other deductions as specified by the Secretary. It also clarifies that certain benefits are disregarded in determining allowable benefits, without affecting other common law doctrines. The subsection outlines guidelines for net tax benefits on leased property, excluding certain deductions. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations, including exemptions. The amendments apply to transactions after the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 6662B imposes penalties for understatements related to transactions lacking economic substance. Penalties are imposed for noneconomic substance transaction understatements, with a 40 percent penalty added to the tax amount. This penalty can be reduced to 20 percent if the relevant facts are adequately disclosed. Noneconomic substance transaction understatement refers to any amount that would be an understatement under specific sections of the tax code. The penalty for noneconomic substance transactions is applied by considering transactions lacking economic substance or not meeting legal requirements. Rules for compromising penalties apply after the taxpayer's review opportunity. The Internal Revenue Service Office of Appeals can only compromise penalties related to certain sections. The penalty imposed by this section is in addition to any other penalties under this title. The penalty imposed under this section is coordinated with other understatements and penalties under different sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Coordination with penalties imposed by section 6662B is specified, and adjustments are made to subsection (e) of section 6662A regarding noneconomic substance transaction understatements. The penalty under this section is coordinated with penalties under different sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including section 6662B. Amendments are made to subsection (e) of section 6662A for noneconomic substance transaction understatements. The term 'noneconomic substance transaction understatement' is defined in section 6662B(c). Section 6707A is amended to include penalties under sections 6662B and 6662(h) for certain transactions. The table of sections for part II of subchapter A of chapter 68 is amended to include penalties under sections 6662B and 6662(h) for certain transactions. The amendments made by this section apply to transactions entered into after the date of the enactment of this Act.
